Chapter 6, Part 3: Distinguishing the Noble Ones. It has already been explained that those who abide in the fruit but have not yet eliminated the afflictions to be eliminated in cultivation are called stream-enterers, who will be reborn a maximum of seven times.
Now, next, we should discuss the assembly of noble ones who have eliminated [afflictions]. First, we should establish the approach and fruit of once-returners.
Verse:
Eliminating three or four categories of desire realm [afflictions], three or two lifetimes as a family-to-family [non-returner].
Eliminating up to five, two approaches; eliminating six, the fruit of once-returning.
Commentary:
The stream-enterer who progresses to eliminate the afflictions to be eliminated in cultivation, if endowed with three conditions, is called a family-to-family [non-returner]:
First, due to eliminating afflictions, having eliminated three or four categories of afflictions to be eliminated in cultivation in the desire realm.
Second, due to perfecting faculties, having obtained the uncontaminated faculties that can counteract those [afflictions].
Third, due to accepting rebirth, having three or two more lifetimes in the desire realm.

The verse only mentions the first and last conditions, because after the fruit of stream-entry, it is said that one progresses to eliminate afflictions and perfects the uncontaminated faculties that can counteract those [afflictions].
The meaning is already established, so it is not fully explained.
However, it should be explained that some are born three or two times, because there is progress, and they are born with few or none, or more than this.
Why is there no one who cuts off five categories?
Because if one cuts off the fifth, one must cut off the sixth. One category of affliction cannot obstruct the attainment of the fruit, just as one interval is not yet beyond the realm.

It should be known that there are generally two kinds of family-to-family:ğŸ”½First, family-to-family in the heavens, which means being born in three or two families in the heavenly realm and realizing nirvana, either in one heavenly place or two or three.
Second, family-to-family among humans, which means being born in three or two families in the human realm and realizing nirvana, either in one continent or two or three.

The one who has entered the path of the fruit of stream-enterer and has eliminated one to five categories of the innate afflictions of the desire realm is called the one who is progressing toward the fruit of once-returner. If he eliminates the sixth category, he becomes a once-returner. He is called a once-returner because he returns to this world only once from the heavens. After this, there is no more rebirth.
He is also called one who is thin in greed, anger, and delusion, because only the inferior categories of greed, anger, and delusion remain.
Having explained the distinctions of the approachers and abiders of the fruit of once-returner, next we will establish the approachers and abiders of the fruit of non-returner.
The verse says:
Those who have eliminated seven or eight categories are called one-intervener.
This is the third approacher, and those who have eliminated nine are the fruit of non-returner.
The treatise says:
The once-returner who has progressed to eliminate the remaining afflictions is called one-intervener when three conditions are met:
First, by eliminating afflictions, he has eliminated seven or eight categories of innate afflictions of the desire realm.
Second, by perfecting faculties, he has obtained the undefiled faculties that can counteract those [afflictions].
The third is due to rebirth, because one still undergoes one more rebirth in the desire realm.
The verse only mentions the first and last two conditions, and does not mention the formation of faculties. The meaning is as explained above.
How does one category of delusion obstruct the attainment of the fruit of non-returner?
Because if it is eliminated, one transcends the realm.

It was previously said that karma is the greatest obstruction during the three periods of time. You should know that afflictions are also the same as karma, because they transcend the stage of the homogeneous cause and the fully ripened effect of that realm.
Interval means an interval. Because one more rebirth is an interval, one does not realize complete nirvana.
Or because one category of remaining delusions to be eliminated by cultivation is an interval, one does not attain the fruit of non-returner.

One who has one interval is called one interval, that is, one who has eliminated seven or eight categories of delusions of the realm of desire to be eliminated by cultivation. You should know that he is also called the candidate for the fruit of non-returner.

One who has previously eliminated three, four, seven, or eight categories of delusions of the realm of desire to be eliminated by the path of cultivation and enters the path of insight, even though he has attained the fruit, as long as he has not yet cultivated the superior path of the subsequent fruit, he is still not called a once-returner or one interval, because he has not yet formed the pure faculties that counteract those delusions.
If one severs the ninth and becomes a nonreturner, one will definitely not return to be reborn in the desire realm.
This affliction is called the severing of the five lower bonds. Although one necessarily first severs either two or three, at this time they are severed collectively.
In the stage of nonreturner, the various scriptures establish distinctions through various approaches. Next, we should discern their distinct characteristics.
The verse says:
Here, there are those who are born and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through practice,
Those who go upstream, if they cultivate a mixture of dhyÄnas, can go to the peak of existence,
Those who transcend half, those who transcend all, and those who die in all abodes, the rest can go to the peak of existence,
Those who practice the formless realm are of four kinds, and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a while dwelling here.
The treatise says:
This nonreturner is said to be of seven kinds in total. First, those who go to the form realm are of five kinds:

1. those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, 2. those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon birth, 3. those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through practice, 4. those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice, 5. those who go upstream.
Because they attain nirvana in the middle, they are called those who attain nirvana in the middle.
In this way, it should be understood that they attain nirvana after birth, either through effort or spontaneously, so they are called those who attain nirvana after birth, and so on.
Because they ascend to a higher realm, they are called those who ascend to a higher realm.
Those who attain nirvana in the middle are those who go to the form realm and attain nirvana in the intermediate state of existence.
Those who attain nirvana after birth are those who go to the form realm and attain nirvana not long after birth, because they have cultivated the path of swift progress with effort.
The nirvana mentioned here refers to nirvana with remainder.
Some say:
It also refers to nirvana without remainder.
This is unreasonable, because they have no mastery over abandoning life.

Those who attain nirvana through practice are those who go to the form realm and attain nirvana after a long time of practice without cessation, through much effort, because they only cultivate with effort and lack the path of swift progress.

Those who attain nirvana without practice are those who go to the form realm and are born there after a long time, and then attain nirvana without much effort, because they lack the diligent cultivation of the path of rapid progress.
Some say:
The difference between these two is that they attain nirvana by relying on conditioned and unconditioned noble paths, respectively.
This explanation is unreasonable, because it is too broad.
However, the sutras first speak of those who attain nirvana without practice and then those who attain nirvana with practice, because this sequence accords with reason.
Because those who attain nirvana without practice and with practice accomplish their goals without and with effort, respectively.
Those who attain nirvana upon birth attain the most rapid and highest level of the path, and because their latent afflictions are the most inferior, they attain nirvana soon after birth.
Those who go upward are those who go upward, because the meanings of going and going upward are the same.
That is, one who dies in the realm of desire and is born in the realm of form does not immediately realize cessation there but must be reborn above in order to attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
This upward progress is of two kinds, because of differences of cause and result.
The difference of cause is due to the fact that there is a mixture of trance states or not.
The difference of result is that the highest peak of existence and the summit of existence are the ultimate destinations.
That is, if one has a mixture of trance states, one can go to the highest peak of existence and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
This is of three kinds, because of differences of total overcoming, half overcoming, and complete death.

Total overcoming means that one who in the realm of desire has already mixed the four trance states loses the three higher trance states because of encountering conditions, and by the condition of craving the bliss of the first trance state, oneâ€™s life ends and one is reborn in the heaven of great Brahma.

By the power of their repeated practice in previous lives, they are able to mix the fourth trance state and, having died from that state, are born in the heaven of the summit of existence. They die in the first place and are born in the last heaven, suddenly passing over the intermediate heavens, which is the meaning of total transcendence.

Those who are half transcenders are born in the lower pure abodes in order, and finally are born in the heaven of the summit of existence, having passed over one place, because their transcendence is not total, it is called half transcendence.
Holy beings are definitely not born in the heaven of the great brahma kings, because that place is perverse in views and has only one leader.
Those who die everywhere are born in all places in order, and finally are able to be born in the heaven of the summit of existence, because they die in all places, it is called dying everywhere.
There are no nonreturners who experience a second birth in the place where they were born, because they seek to advance to a superior place of birth, not to an equal or inferior one.
It is precisely because of this that the meaning of nonreturner is fulfilled, because they definitely do not return to be born in the place where they were born.
They do not even take rebirth in their original place, much less in a lower level.

You should understand that the first of the two kinds of saints who are upper stream, because they have cultivated the causes of the samÄdhi of cessation, go to the peak of existence and there enter nirvana. The second kind, who do not cultivate the samÄdhi of cessation, go to the highest heaven of the formless realm and there enter nirvana. That is, they do not cultivate the samÄdhi of cessation, and because of craving for the various samÄdhis, they die in the form realm and are reborn in all the heavens of the form realm, but they are unable to go to the five pure heavenly abodes.
They die in the formless realm and are reborn in the three heavens of the formless realm in order, and finally they are reborn in the highest heaven of the formless realm and there enter nirvana.

Of the two kinds of upper stream, the first is a saint who practices contemplation, and the second is a saint who practices stopping, because they differ in whether they prefer wisdom or concentration.

It is not contrary to reason to say that the two kinds of upper stream enter nirvana in a lower heaven, but it is said that they go to the peak of existence and the highest heaven of the formless realm as their ultimate destination, because beyond these there is no place to go, just as the stream-winner is reborn a maximum of seven times.
These five are called those who proceed to the form realm.

Those who proceed to the formless realm are of four types, namely, in the desire realm, they are free from craving for the form realm, and from there, at the end of their life, they are born in the formless realm.
Here, there are only four types, because there are differences in the parinirvÄá¹‡a attained through birth. Together with the previous five, there are six non-returners.

There are also those who do not proceed to the form or formless realms, but right here, they are able to attain parinirvÄá¹‡a, called parinirvÄá¹‡a upon manifesting. Together with the previous six, there are seven.
Among the five non-returners who proceed to the form realm, there is another category that distinguishes them.
The verse says:
There are nine who proceed to the form realm, each divided into three,
Because of differences in karma, afflictions, and faculties, they become nine types.
The treatise says:
The five types of non-returners who proceed to the form realm are generally established as three, each divided into three types, thus becoming nine types.
What are the three?
Because of differences in the middle, birth, and upper stream.
How are these three each divided into three?
The parinirvÄá¹‡a of those of the middle grade is divided into three types: parinirvÄá¹‡a quickly, not quickly, and after a long time, because this is shown by the three analogies of fire.
The parinirvÄá¹‡a of those of the birth class is also divided into three types, because there is parinirvÄá¹‡a with practice, etc., in the next life.
All of these attain parinirvÄá¹‡a after birth, and therefore they should all be called those of the birth class.
In the case of those of the upper grade, there are also three types, because there are distinctions of transcendence, half transcendence, etc.
However, all of these three types quickly, not quickly, and after a long time attain parinirvÄá¹‡a, and therefore there is no confusion in comparing them with each other.

These three types of nonreturners, nine in all, are not the same in being quick, not quick, and slow because of differences in karma, passions, and faculties. In general, they are divided into three because of the differences in the karma that is done and increased that is favorable to birth and to post-death existence.

Because there are differences in the manifestation of the three grades of afflictions, and because there are differences in the three grades of faculties, these three each have three kinds according to their respective cases.
Also, because there are differences in karma, afflictions, and faculties, each has three distinctions, thus making nine kinds.
That is to say, the first two and the third are each divided into three kinds due to differences in afflictions and faculties, not due to differences in karma;

The last three are also divided into three kinds due to differences in karma that accords with the next life. Therefore, it is said that the non-returners who proceed to the form realm are distinguished into three groups of nine due to differences in karma, afflictions, and faculties.
If that is so, why did the Buddha only speak of seven courses of the worthy in the sutras?
The verse says:
The seven courses of the worthy are established based on the distinctions in the highest type of non-returner.
Because of good and evil conduct, and because of going and not returning.
The treatise says:
The middle and rebirth types each have three, and the highest type is one. The sutra establishes the seven courses of the worthy based on this.
Because they have the Dharma of going upstream, they are called those who go upstream. Because of this same meaning, they are provisionally established as one.
Why is the designation of good persons established only on the basis of these and not on the basis of the remaining learners?
The meaning of â€œgoingâ€ is the meaning of practice. The remaining learners all practice good karma without distinction.
Only these seven kinds both practice good karma and do not practice evil karma, while the others are not like this.
Moreover, only these seven kinds go up to the upper realms and do not return again, while the others are not like this.
Therefore, the designation of good persons is established only on the basis of these.
If that is so, why does a scripture say:
â€œWhat is a good person?
It is said that if one possesses right view of the learner stage, and so on, and so forth.â€

The remaining learners, if one takes a different perspective, can also be said to have the nature of good persons, because the learners all obtain the precept of never committing the five kinds of evil, and because they have already eliminated much of the unwholesome and afflictions.
The term â€œgood destiniesâ€ is established from the perspective of only practicing good and not practicing evil, and only relying on superior causes to ascend to the upper realms.
Do those who have already experienced birth in the noble stage also have these distinctions?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
The verse says:
The noble ones who have experienced birth in the desire realm do not go to be born in other realms.
Those who have ascended to the upper realms have neither cultivated their faculties nor regressed.
The treatise says:

The noble ones who have experienced birth in the desire realm definitely do not go to be born in the form and formless realms, because having realized the fruit of non-returner, they definitely attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the present body.
If the noble ones who have experienced birth in the form realm are able to ascend to be born in the formless realm, it is like those who practice up to the peak of existence in the form realm.
However, Sakra DevÄnÄm-Indra said:
I have heard of a heaven called Akaniá¹£á¹­ha. After I fall back, I will be born there.
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters explain it like this:
Because they do not understand the characteristics of the Abhidharma, and in order to please them, the Buddha also did not prohibit it.
Those who have already been reborn in the desire realm and those who have already been reborn in higher realms, the noble ones, definitely do not have the cultivation of faculties or retrogression.
Why is it not allowed that the noble ones who have been reborn in the desire realm and who have been reborn in higher realms have the cultivation of faculties and retrogression?
Because it is definitely not the case.
Why is it definitely not the case?
Because the faculties cultivated through rebirth are extremely mature, and because they have attained a superior basis.
Why are there no learners who have not yet eliminated desire who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state?
Because their noble path is not yet fully mature, it is not yet able to be manifested, and the latent tendencies that they possess are not extremely weak.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas give the following explanation:

Because the dharmas of the realm of desire are extremely difficult to transcend, because there is still much to be done, that is, because one must progress to eliminate the two passions of the good and indeterminate, and because one must progress to obtain the two or three fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, and because one must totally transcend the dharmas of the three realms, one who abides in the intermediate state has no such ability.

It was previously said that the upper stream, by cultivating the various concentrations as a cause, is able to go to the heaven of the ultimate end of form. First, one should cultivate the various concentrations.
By what state is it known that the various concentrations are accomplished?
And for what reason does one cultivate the various concentrations?
The verse says:
First, one cultivates the various fourth concentrations, accomplished by a single thought of various,
In order to experience birth, present happiness, and prevent the retrogression of passions.
The treatise says:

Those who cultivate the various four concentrations must first cultivate the various fourth concentrations, because that samÄdhi is the most capable, and because among the various practices of happiness, it is the most excellent.

One who cultivates these various samÄdhis is either an arhat or an anÄgÄmin. He must first enter the fourth trance and manifest many moments of pure concentration in succession. From this he produces many moments of impure concentration, and then again many moments of pure concentration manifest. In this way, he gradually reduces the number of moments in succession until finally he has two moments of pure concentration, which then induce two moments of impure concentration to manifest. Immediately after this, two moments of pure concentration are again produced, and this is called the completion of the preparatory practice of the samÄdhi of mixed cultivation.

Next, only from one moment of pure concentration is one moment of impure concentration induced to manifest, and immediately after this one moment of pure concentration is produced. Because the moment of impure concentration in the middle is mixed with the moments of pure concentration before and after it, it is called the perfect completion of the fundamental samÄdhi of mixed cultivation.
The first two moments are similar to the uninterrupted path, and the third moment is similar to the path of liberation.
Having thus cultivated the fourth trance in a mixed manner, by the power of this he is also able to cultivate the lower three trances in a mixed manner, as appropriate.

Having first cultivated these various meditations in the human realm of the desire realm, if one later regresses and is reborn in the form realm, one is also able to cultivate these various meditations as before.
The cultivation of various meditations has three kinds of conditions:
First, for the sake of rebirth; second, for the sake of present happiness; third, for the sake of preventing regression due to the arising of afflictions.
That is to say, among the non-returners, those of sharp faculties cultivate for the sake of present happiness and to be reborn in the Pure Abodes.
Those of dull faculties also cultivate for the sake of preventing regression, because they fear regression.
In this way, they cultivate various meditations in order to distance themselves from the samÄdhi that is relished.

As for the arhats, those of sharp faculties cultivate for the sake of present happiness, while those of dull faculties also cultivate for the sake of preventing the arising of afflictions and regression, cultivating various meditations in order to be reborn in the Pure Abodes.
Why are there only five Pure Abodes?
The verse states:
Due to the cultivation of five grades, there are five Pure Abodes.
The treatise states:
Because there are five grades of mixed cultivation of the fourth trance state, the Pure Abodes are only five.
What are the five grades?
They are called inferior, medium, superior, superior-superior, and extreme grades.
In this case, the first grade is completed by the manifestation of three minds, namely, the first pure mind, next the contaminated mind, and then the pure mind.
The second grade is six, the third grade is nine, the fourth grade is twelve, and the fifth grade is fifteen.
In this way, the five grades of mixed cultivation of the trances correspond to the five Pure Abodes.
It should be understood that in this case, the power of the pure mind perfuming and cultivating the contaminated mind causes it to attract the Pure Abodes.
Other masters say:
The five beginning with faith attract the five Pure Abodes in the order of their predominance.
The scriptures say that nonreturners are called bodily witnesses.
On the basis of what superior qualities is the name bodily witness established?
A verse says:
Nonreturners who attain the concentration of cessation are called bodily witnesses.
The treatise says:

One who has acquired the attainment of cessation is called one who has acquired the attainment of cessation. If one who has not yet returned to this world has the attainment of cessation in his body, he is called one who has realized with the body.
That is to say, because one who has not yet returned to this world realizes with his body a state that resembles nirvÄá¹‡a, he is called one who has realized with the body.
How is it said that he is called one who has realized with the body?
Because his mind is absent and because he is born in dependence on the body.
In reality, it should be said that when he arises from the attainment of cessation, he acquires for the first time a body that is tranquil and endowed with consciousness, and he thinks,
This attainment of cessation is most tranquil and most resembles nirvÄá¹‡a.
In this way, he realizes the tranquility of the body, and therefore he is called one who has realized with the body.

Because he realizes the tranquility of the body through the acquisition of the attainment of cessation and through the realization of the knowledge of its realization, the scriptures speak of eighteen kinds of learners.
Why is it that he is not mentioned among them?
Because the causes for their existence are absent.
What are the causes for their existence?
That is to say, the three learnings and their fruits are uncontaminated. They are established on the basis of their differences.
The samÄdhi of cessation is neither a learner nor the fruit of a learner, and therefore learners are not distinguished on the basis of attaining it.
The gross characteristics of the differences among nonreturners are as just explained. If we analyze them in detail, their number becomes many thousands.
What is the meaning of this?
First, if we establish differences among nonreturners on the basis of their faculties, they are of three kinds, because there are differences of inferior, medium, and superior faculties.
If we establish differences on the basis of their stages, they are of four kinds, because there are differences of those who go to the first trance state, etc.
If we establish differences on the basis of their spiritual lineages, they are of six kinds, because there are differences of the spiritual lineages of those liable to regress, etc.
If we establish differences on the basis of their abodes, they are of sixteen kinds, because there are differences of the BrahmakÄyika realm, etc.

If we establish differences on the basis of the degrees of freedom from the passions of the form realm, they are of thirty-six kinds, because there are differences of those who are bound to all the stages of the form realm up to those who are free from the eighth degree of passion of the fourth trance state.
If we establish differences on the basis of abodes, spiritual lineages, degrees of freedom from the passions, and faculties, there are a total of 2,592 kinds of nonreturners.
How is this so?

In one place, there are six types of spiritual faculties. Each type of spiritual faculty is distinguished by the door of detachment, resulting in nine types. Beginning with one who is bound by all fetters in any stage, up to one who has already detached from the eighth category, there are thus six times nine, making fifty-four. Taking the sixteen places and multiplying by fifty-four, there are eight hundred and sixty-four. Multiplying by the three faculties again, the total becomes two thousand five hundred and ninety-two.

Those who have detached from the ninth category of defilements of the lower stages are called those bound by all fetters in the upper stages. This is because the number of detachments for each stage is the same.
In this way, up to the stream-enterers of the highest fruit are also like this.
In total, the five types are accumulated to form twelve thousand nine hundred and sixty.
The distinctions of the third approach and fruit have already been explained. Next, the fourth approach and fruit should be established.
Verse:ğŸ”½In the upper realms, in the afflictions of the meditation stages,ğŸ”½Cutting off the first stage, up to the peak of existence, in the eighth stage,
All are approaches to arhatship.
The ninth uninterrupted path is called the vajra-like samÄdhi.
At the end, one attains the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising, and becomes an arhat, a perfected one.
The treatise says:

The non-returner who further eliminates the afflictions to be eliminated through cultivation in the form and formless realms, starting from eliminating the first stage of the first concentration up to eliminating the eighth stage of the peak of existence, should be known as turning to become a candidate for arhatship.

Among those who are called candidates for arhatship, the ninth uninterrupted path that eliminates the afflictions of the peak of existence is also called the vajra-like samÄdhi, because it can destroy all the latent tendencies. It is because they have already been destroyed.
It does not actually destroy all, but it has the ability to destroy all.
Because this samÄdhi is the most excellent among the uninterrupted paths that can eliminate afflictions.

The diamond-like samÄdhi is said to have many kinds, that is, it arises as the uninterrupted path that severs the ninth category of the affliction of the peak of existence, and it is generally based on the nine stages. Therefore, it is said that this samÄdhi is distinguished by the differences of cognition, object, and practice. It is included in the stage of the preliminary concentration and has fifty-two. That is, the cognition of suffering and origination of the class of cognition of the peak of existence each have four aspects, and the corresponding [cognition] is eight. The cognition of cessation and path of the cognition of the dharma each have four aspects, and the corresponding [cognition] is eight. The cognition of cessation of the class of cognition of the eight stages each has four aspects, and the corresponding [cognition] is thirty-two in total. The cognition of the path of the class of cognition of the eight stages generally has four aspects, and the corresponding [cognition] is four, because the path of the same class that counteracts the eight stages must be the universal cause.
Just as it is included in the preliminary concentration and has fifty-two, it should be known that the four middle concentrations are also like this.

The sphere of infinite space has twenty-eight, the sphere of infinite consciousness has twenty-four, and the sphere of nothingness has twenty, because in the formless [realms] there is no cognition of the dharma or the cognition of cessation of the lower [realms].
However, the path that takes the lower stages as its object is the cause of each other because they are of the same class.
Some say:
This concentration and knowledge have different objects.

The anÄgamya stage includes eighty kinds, that is, the knowledge of the classes of the path that takes the eight stages as its object, each of which also has four aspects that correspond to it. For this reason, it increases by twenty-eight more than the previous.
Just as the anÄgamya stage includes eighty kinds, the four intermediate meditations should be understood in the same way.
The sphere of infinite space has forty, the sphere of infinite consciousness has thirty-two, and the sphere of nothingness has twenty-four.

There are also those who want to make the knowledge of the diamond-like concentration different from its object. The anÄgamya stage includes a total of one hundred and sixty-four kinds, that is, the knowledge of the classes of cessation that takes the cessation of the eight stages as its object, each of which has four aspects that correspond to it. For this reason, it increases by one hundred and twelve more than the previous.
Just as the anÄgamya stage includes one hundred and sixty-four, the four intermediate meditations should be understood in the same way.
The formless realm has three levels: the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, and the sphere of nothingness.
If we analyze according to type, faculties, etc., there are many more kinds, as should be understood from the principles explained above.

Since this samÄdhi can eliminate the ninth class of passions of the summit of existence, it can induce the knowledge of the exhaustion of contamination that accompanies the acquisition of the elimination of those passions and make it arise.

The vajra-like samÄdhi is the final uninterrupted path in the elimination of passions. The knowledge of the exhaustion of contamination is the final path of liberation in the elimination of passions, because this path of liberation is the first to be accompanied by the acquisition of the elimination of all contaminations and is therefore called knowledge of the exhaustion of contamination.
When this knowledge of the exhaustion of contamination has already arisen, one becomes an arhat, a post-learner, because one has acquired the dharmas of a post-learner who is a perfected being.
Because there is nothing more to be learned or cultivated in order to acquire a separate result, one is called a post-learner.
This person is called an arhat because he is only worthy of worship by those who are defiled.
This meaning is established by implication.
The four candidates and three fruit-attainers that have been discussed above are all called learners. What is the reason that the first seven are called learners?
Because they constantly delight in learning in order to attain the destruction of contamination.
Learning must have three aspects:
1. superior morality, 2. superior concentration, 3. superior wisdom.
Morality, concentration, and wisdom are the three natures of learning.
If this is so, then ordinary beings should be called learners.
No, because they have not yet seen and known the truth of reality, and because they may later lose correct learning. For this reason, the Well-Gone One repeats the word learning.
As a scripture says, the Buddha told Dhyana:
Learning what should be learned, learning what should be learned, I only call this one a learner.
In order to make them understand that one who learns what should be learned without losing it is called a learner, the BhagavÄn repeats the word learning.
How can the noble ones who abide in their intrinsic nature be called learners?
Because their intention to learn is not yet fulfilled.
It is like a practitioner who temporarily rests or who has attained the Dharma that always follows.
What is the Dharma of training?
It refers to the conditioned, impure dharmas of one who is still learning.
What is the Dharma of no-more-training?
It refers to the conditioned, impure dharmas of one who is beyond training.
Why is nirvÄá¹‡a not called the Dharma of training?
